properties.Title: Update To Civil Emergency Alert Issued By Government Of Saskatchewan
properties.Summary:
Description: This Alert is issued by the Government of Saskatchewan. The state of emergency in Saskatchewan has been extended. Keep following the orders of the Chief Medical Health Officer. Practice physical distancing. Avoid gatherings with people outside your immediate household. Avoid unnecessary travel. Self-isolate if returning from foreign travel or if experiencing any symptoms. Wash your hands often. Together, we are reducing the risk. We can pull together by staying apart.
Expires: 2020-04-04T12:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2020-04-03T16:00:11-06:00, 297C2974-BB61-BEBC-8AE9-6F280FCEB8B9
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant early April snowfall today into tonight. A large area of snow will whiten Northwestern Ontario this afternoon and tonight in the wake of a cold front moving through the region. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are expected across the region, with local amounts of 10 to 15 cm possible near the Manitoba border by Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T07:56:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-03T15:57:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3024573654.2020
Area: Red Lake - Woodland Caribou Park, Ear Falls - Perrault Falls - Western Lac Seul
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall will continue over parts of northern Manitoba tonight and saturday. The heaviest snow will occur along a line from Tadoule Lake through the northern Thompson region and then to Gillam. The heaviest snow will occur north of the city of Thompson, however the city of Thompson should still expect snow totals of 25 cm by Saturday evening with the bulk of of the snow coming today and tonight. In Gillam, light snow is expected to rapidly intensify this evening and bring 10 to 15 cm by morning and an additional 15 to 25 cm on Saturday and Saturday night. Light snow will then continue into Sunday before clearing Sunday evening. Total snowfall amounts of 40 to 45 cm are possible for Gillam. In Tadoule Lake and area, heavy snow is expected to continue until Sunday morning with 10 to 15 cm today, an additional 10 to 15 cm tonight and an additional 10 to 15 cm on Saturday and Saturday night. Total snowfall amounts of 45 to 50 cm are possible for Tadoule Lake and area. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T11:24:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-03T19:25:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3607009825.2020
Area: Tadoule Lake, South Indian Lake and Amisk Prov. Park, Split Lake and York Landing, Thompson Thicket Portage and Pikwitonei, Nelson House, Gillam
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow will continue for today for areas east of Wollaston Lake to Four Corners Canada. Through today, up to 10 cm of snow is expected to accumulate, on top of the 10 to 20 cm that fell on Thursday and Thursday night. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T07:59:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-03T16:31:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0518002480.2020
Area: Wollaston Lake - Collins Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:
Description: A few daily low temperature records were set today (April 3rd) Chetwynd Area New Record -26 Old Record -24 set in 2007 Records began in 1970 Dawson Creek Area New Record -30.2 Old Record -26.8 set in 2002 Records began in 1926 Mackenzie Area New Record -21.8 Old Record -20.6 set in 2007 Records began in 1971 Smithers Area Tied record of -13.9 set in 2002 Records began in 1938 ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T10:35:34-00:00

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Continued For The Red River Between Emerson And The Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Red River between Emerson and the Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2020-04-04T12:00:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-04-03T13:20:19-05:00, D7A791C4-0E6F-CB5E-9284-52B48CC08C7F
Area: The Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Early April snowfall tonight. Rain or a rain and wet snow mix will turn over to snow this evening as a sharp arctic cold front moves through. Total snowfall amounts of 2 to 5 cm are likely by the time the snow ends by morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T07:59:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-04T01:54:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4040701773.2020
Area: Sandy Lake - Weagamow Lake - Deer Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A slow moving cold front will continue to bring significant snowfall to central and northern Manitoba over the next couple of days. In Poplar River, an additional 2 to 4 cm is expected this evening before tapering off later overnight. In the northwest, snow will continue heavy at times this evening, then the main area of snow will shift north of the community of Brochet later tonight and Saturday. In the north central areas of Norway House and Island Lake, heavy snow will continue until Saturday morning with an additional 5 to 10 cm. Total snowfall for this area is expected to be 15 to 25 cm. In Shamattawa, light snow is expected to intensify this evening and remain heavy until Saturday evening. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm can be expected this evening with an additional 10 to 15 cm on Saturday for totals of 20 to 25 cm. In Churchill, snow is expected to persist until Sunday evening with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm, however, areas south of Churchill can expect snow to intensify rapidly overnight and remain heavy for Saturday and Saturday night. Total snowfall for areas just south of Churchill are expected to reach 25 to 25 cm by Monday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T12:34:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-03T20:35:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2692357105.2020
Area: Poplar River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A slow moving cold front will continue to bring significant snowfall to central and northern Manitoba over the next couple of days. In the south, snow will taper off from west to east throughout the day today. In Winnipeg, the Red River Valley and Interlake, the snow will end some time this morning with further amounts of only a couple of centimetres. It should end this afternoon in the Whiteshell, with up to 4 more centimetres in the forecast, and this evening around Berens River with 5 to 10 more centimetres likely. In the north, snow will continue heavy at times today, then the main area of snow will shift northeastward towards Gillam and Churchill for tonight and Saturday. Total snowfalls of 15 to 25 cm are likely in most areas, although parts of north-central Manitoba could top the 30 cm mark. Finally on Sunday, the snow over northeastern Manitoba should also come to an end as the system finally weakens. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T07:13:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-03T15:14:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3641978180.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant early April snowfall is expected tonight into Saturday morning. Wet snow mixed with rain will move into the region this evening then turn over to snow which will continue overnight before tapering to scattered flurries by noon on Saturday. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by midday Saturday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief freezing rain possible this evening, A few patches of freezing rain are possible as occasional rain switches over to ice pellets then snow early this evening in the wake of a sharp arctic cold front moving through the region. Total snowfall amounts of 2 to 5 centimetres are expected. Some ice accretion is most likely on elevated surfaces. Untreated highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may also become icy and slippery. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination as poor winter driving conditions are expected. The snow will end overnight as the cold front moves away to the east. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T06:59:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-03T20:25:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4068597237.2020
Area: Atikokan - Shebandowan - Quetico Park

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief freezing rain possible tonight. Rain will move in from Minnesota this evening, then change through ice pellets to snow near midnight. Snow will persist into the overnight hours. The ice pellets may be briefly mixed at times with a little freezing rain. Poor winter driving conditions are expected. Untreated highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may also become icy and slippery. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination tonight. Freezing rain warnings are not anticipated. Environment Canada continues to closely monitor this situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-04T07:59:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-04T01:56:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0866277936.2020
Area: City of Thunder Bay, Cloud Bay - Dorion, Kakabeka Falls - Whitefish Lake - Arrow Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada
